children.displayTitle: 1203.3 Unvented Attic and Unvented Enclosed Rafter Assemblies

children.body: The provisions of this chapter shall govern ventilation, temperature control, lighting, yards and courts, sound transmission, room dimensions, surrounding materials and rodentproofing associated with the interior spaces of buildings.

The following terms are defined in Chapter 2:
SUNROOM.
THERMAL ISOLATION.

diagrams.title: Vent Free Attics: Option 1 - Only Air-Impermeable Insulation
Vent Free Attics: Option 2 - Air-Permeable Insulation
Vent Free Attics: Option 3 - Air-Permeable & Air-Impermeable Insulation
Vent Free Attics: Option 4 - Rigid Insulation
Vent Free Attics: Option 5 - Vapor Diffusion Port
Ventilation of Rafter Spaces with Ceilings Directly Attached
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Where the ceiling is directly applied to the underside of roof rafters, cross ventilation of the rafter space is required. The rafter space ventilation openings are required to be protected from the entry of snow and rain. Where insulation is installed a 1" minimum clearance is required between the roof sheathing and the insulation. Blocking and bridging within the rafter spaces shall not block the free flow of air.

diagrams.title: Example: Ventilation of Attics - Conventional Attics
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Enclosed attics and rafter spaces enclosed by ceilings directly applied to rafters are required to have cross ventilation. The minimum amount of required ventilation is defined in the code.

diagrams.title: Example: Ventilation of Attics - Clg. Applied Directly to Roof Rafters
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Enclosed attics and rafter spaces enclosed by ceilings directly applied to rafters are required to have cross ventilation. The minimum amount of required ventilation is defined in the code.

Where the ceiling is applied directly to the underside of the roof rafters, each enclosed rafter space must be provided with the minimum required ventilation. The code requires a minimum net free ventilation area greater than or equal to 1/150th of the area being enclosed. The net free ventilation provided by a ventilation product is typically provided by the manufacturer of the ventilation product and is typically provided in square inches. It is important to make sure that units of the required ventilation and the provided ventilation are the same when checking calculations for compliance.

children.body:
Buildings shall be provided with natural ventilation in accordance with Section 1203.4, or mechanical ventilation in accordance with the Florida Building Code, Mechanical.
Where the air infiltration rate in a dwelling unit is less than 3 air changes per hour when tested with a blower door at a pressure 0.2 inch w.c. (50 Pa) in accordance with Section R402.4.1.2 of the Florida Building Code, Energy Conservation—Residential Provisions, the dwelling unit shall be ventilated by mechanical means in accordance with Section 403 of the Florida Building Code, Mechanical. Ambulatory care facilities and Group I-2 occupancies shall be ventilated by mechanical means in accordance with Section 407 of the Florida Building Code, Mechanical.

Enclosed attics and enclosed rafter spaces formed where ceilings are applied directly to the underside of roof framing members shall have cross ventilation for each separate space by ventilation openings protected against the entrance of rain and snow. Blocking, bridging, and insulation shall be arranged so as not to interfere with the movement of air. An airspace of not less than 1 inch (25 mm) shall be provided between the insulation and the roof sheathing. The net free ventilating area shall be not less than 1/150 of the area of the space ventilated. Ventilators shall be installed in accordance with manufacturer's installation instructions.
Exception: The net free cross-ventilation area shall be permitted to be reduced to 1/300 provided at least 40 percent and not more than 50 percent of the required venting area is provided by ventilators located in the upper portion of the attic or rafter space. Upper ventilators shall be located not more than 3 feet (914 mm) below the ridge or highest point of the space, measured vertically, with the balance of the ventilation provided by eave or cornice vents. Where the location of wall or roof framing members conflicts with the installation of upper ventilators, installation more than 3 feet (914 mm) below the ridge or highest point of the space shall be permitted.

diagrams.title: Attic Draftstopping (FL)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Draftstop: A material, device or construction installed to restrict the movement of air within open spaces of concealed areas of building components such as crawl spaces, floor/ceiling assemblies, roof/ceiling assemblies and attics.

diagrams.title: Attic Ventilation
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Attic ventilation helps control the temperature and moisture content of the attic space. Provides benefits including allowing the interior space to be more easily cooled in the summer without the added heat load of the attic space which would continue to be present at night, even when the outside air is cooler. Also in cold climates, the warmer air of the attic contributes to the melting of snow and ice, which then refreezes on the eaves, creating an "ice dam" which damages the roofing and other parts of the home. Venting this heat helps reduce this damage.

diagrams.title: Ventilation of Rafter Spaces with Ceilings Directly Attached
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Where the ceiling is directly applied to the underside of roof rafters, cross ventilation of the rafter space is required. The rafter space ventilation openings are required to be protected from the entry of snow and rain. Where insulation is installed a 1" minimum clearance is required between the roof sheathing and the insulation. Blocking and bridging within the rafter spaces shall not block the free flow of air.

diagrams.title: Example: Ventilation of Attics - Conventional Attics
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Enclosed attics and rafter spaces enclosed by ceilings directly applied to rafters are required to have cross ventilation. The minimum amount of required ventilation is defined in the code.

diagrams.title: Example: Ventilation of Attics - Clg. Applied Directly to Roof Rafters
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Enclosed attics and rafter spaces enclosed by ceilings directly applied to rafters are required to have cross ventilation. The minimum amount of required ventilation is defined in the code.

Where the ceiling is applied directly to the underside of the roof rafters, each enclosed rafter space must be provided with the minimum required ventilation. The code requires a minimum net free ventilation area greater than or equal to 1/150th of the area being enclosed. The net free ventilation provided by a ventilation product is typically provided by the manufacturer of the ventilation product and is typically provided in square inches. It is important to make sure that units of the required ventilation and the provided ventilation are the same when checking calculations for compliance.

children.body: Exterior openings into the attic space of any building intended for human occupancy shall be protected to prevent the entry of birds, squirrels, rodents, snakes and other similar creatures. Openings for ventilation having a least dimension of not less than 1/16 inch (1.6 mm) and not more than 1/4 inch (6.4 mm) shall be permitted. Openings for ventilation having a least dimension larger than 1/4 inch (6.4 mm) shall be provided with corrosion-resistant wire cloth screening, hardware cloth, perforated vinyl or similar material with openings having a least dimension of not less than 1/16 inch (1.6 mm) and not more than 1/4 inch (6.4 mm). Where combustion air is obtained from an attic area, it shall be in accordance with Chapter 7 of the Florida Building Code, Mechanical.

Unvented attics and unvented enclosed roof framing assemblies created by ceilings applied directly to the underside of the roof framing members/rafters and the structural roof sheathing at the top of the roof framing members shall be permitted where all the following conditions are met:
  1. The unvented attic space is completely within the building thermal envelope.
  2. No interior Class I vapor retarders are installed on the ceiling side (attic floor) of the unvented attic assembly or on the ceiling side of the unvented enclosed roof framing assembly.
  3. Where wood shingles or shakes are used, a minimum 1/4-inch (6.4 mm) vented airspace separates the shingles or shakes and the roofing underlayment above the structural sheathing.
  4. In Climate Zones 5, 6, 7 and 8, any air-impermeable insulation shall be a Class II vapor retarder or shall have a Class II vapor retarder coating or covering in direct contact with the underside of the insulation.
  5. Insulation shall comply with either Item 5.1 or 5.2, and additionally Item 5.3.
    1. Item 5.1.1, 5.1.2, 5.1.3 or 5.1.4 shall be met, depending on the air permeability of the insulation directly under the structural roof sheathing.
      1. Where only air-impermeable insulation is provided, it shall be applied in direct contact with the underside of the structural roof sheathing.
      2. Where air-permeable insulation is provided inside the building thermal envelope, it shall be installed in accordance with Item 5.1. In addition to the air-permeable insulation installed directly below the structural sheathing, rigid board or sheet insulation shall be installed directly above the structural roof sheathing in accordance with the R values in Table 1203.3 for condensation control.
      3. Where both air-impermeable and air-permeable insulation are provided, the air-impermeable insulation shall be applied in direct contact with the underside of the structural roof sheathing in accordance with Item 5.1.1 and shall be in accordance with the R values in Table 1203.3 for condensation control. The air-permeable insulation shall be installed directly under the air-impermeable insulation.
      4. Alternatively, sufficient rigid board or sheet insulation shall be installed directly above the structural roof sheathing to maintain the monthly average temperature of the underside of the structural roof sheathing above 45°F (7°C). For calculation purposes, an interior air temperature of 68°F (20°C) is assumed and the exterior air temperature is assumed to be the monthly average outside air temperature of the three coldest months.
    2. In Climate Zones 1, 2 and 3 air-permeable insulation installed in unvented attics shall meet the following requirements:
      1. A vapor diffusion port shall be installed not more than 12 inches (305 mm) from the highest point of the roof, measured vertically from the highest point of the roof to the lower edge of the port.
      2. The port area shall be greater than or equal to 1/600 of the ceiling area. Where there are multiple ports in the attic, the sum of the port areas shall be greater than or equal to the area requirement.
      3. The vapor permeable membrane in the vapor diffusion port shall have a vapor permeance rating of greater than or equal to 20 perms when tested in accordance with Procedure A of ASTM E96.
      4. The vapor diffusion port shall serve as an air barrier between the attic and the exterior of the building.
      5. The vapor diffusion port shall protect the attic against the entrance of rain and snow.
      6. Framing members and blocking shall not block the free flow of water vapor to the port. Not less than a 2-inch (50 mm) space shall be provided between any blocking and the roof sheathing. Air-permeable insulation shall be permitted within that space.
      7. The roof slope shall be greater than or equal to 3 units vertical in 12 units horizontal (3:12).
      8. Where only air-permeable insulation is used, it shall be installed directly below the structural roof sheathing, on top the attic floor, or on top of the ceiling.
      9. Where only air-permeable insulation is used and is installed directly below the structural roof sheathing, air shall be supplied at a flow rate greater than or equal to 50 cubic feet per minute (23.6 L/s) per 1,000 square feet (93 m2) of ceiling.
    3. The air shall be supplied from ductwork providing supply air to the occupiable space when the conditioning system is operating. Alternatively, the air shall be supplied by a supply fan when the conditioning system is operating. Where preformed insulation board is used as the air-impermeable insulation layer, it shall be sealed at the perimeter of each individual sheet interior surface to form a continuous layer.
Exceptions:
  1. Section 1203.3 does not apply to special use structures or enclosures such as swimming pool enclosures, data processing centers, hospitals or art galleries.
  2. Section 1203.3 does not apply to enclosures in Climate Zones 5 through 8 that are humidified beyond 35 percent during the three coldest months.

diagrams.title: Vent Free Attics: Option 1 - Only Air-Impermeable Insulation
Vent Free Attics: Option 2 - Air-Permeable Insulation
Vent Free Attics: Option 3 - Air-Permeable & Air-Impermeable Insulation
Vent Free Attics: Option 4 - Rigid Insulation
Vent Free Attics: Option 5 - Vapor Diffusion Port

children.displayTitle: 1203.3 Unvented Attic and Unvented Enclosed Rafter Assemblies
children.titleText: Unvented Attic and Unvented Enclosed Rafter Assemblies

children.body: The space between the bottom of the floor joists and the earth under any building except spaces occupied by basements or cellars shall be provided with ventilation openings through foundation walls or exterior walls. Such openings shall be placed so as to provide cross ventilation of the under-floor space.

diagrams.title: Under-Floor Ventilation
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Section R408.1 defines the minimum amount of ventilation required to prevent water vapor escaping from the earth from damaging the structure. The aggregate amount of ventilation opening required is defined as 1 sf of net area per 150 sf of enclosed under-floor area. The ventilation opening area required may be reduced to 1 sf of net area per 1500 sf of enclosed under-floor area if a class 1 vapor retarder covering the underfloor ground surface is provided. To take advantage of the reduced ventilation requirements with a vapor retarder the openings are required to be arranged such that they provide cross ventilation of the enclosed under-floor space. The minimum ventilation opening arrangement and locations are also defined. Opening must be provided within 3' of each building corner.

children.body:
The net area of ventilation openings shall be not less than 1 square foot for each 150 square feet (0.67 m2 for each 100 m2) of crawl-space area. Ventilation openings shall be covered for their height and width with any of the following materials, provided that the least dimension of the covering shall be not greater than 1/4 inch (6.4 mm):
  1. Perforated sheet metal plates not less than 0.070 inch (1.8 mm) thick.
  2. Expanded sheet metal plates not less than 0.047 inch (1.2 mm) thick.
  3. Cast-iron grilles or gratings.
  4. Extruded load-bearing vents.
  5. Hardware cloth of 0.035-inch (0.89 mm) wire or heavier.
  6. Corrosion-resistant wire mesh, with the least dimension not greater than 1/8 inch (3.2 mm).

The following are exceptions to Sections 1203.4 and 1203.4.1:
  1. Where warranted by climatic conditions, ventilation openings to the outdoors are not required if ventilation openings to the interior are provided.
  2. The total area of ventilation openings is permitted to be reduced to 1/1,500 of the under-floor area where the ground surface is covered with a Class I vapor retarder material and the required openings are placed so as to provide cross ventilation of the space. The installation of operable louvers shall not be prohibited.
  3. Ventilation openings are not required where continuously operated mechanical ventilation is provided at a rate of 1.0 cubic foot per minute (cfm) for each 50 square feet (1.02 L/s for each 10 m2) of crawlspace floor area and the ground surface is covered with a Class I vapor retarder.
  4. Ventilation openings are not required where the ground surface is covered with a Class I vapor retarder, the perimeter walls are insulated and the space is conditioned in accordance with the Florida Building Code, Energy Conservation.
  5. For buildings in flood hazard areas as established in Section 1612.3, the openings for under-floor ventilation shall be deemed as meeting the flood opening requirements of ASCE 24 provided that the ventilation openings are designed and installed in accordance with ASCE 24.

Natural ventilation of an occupied space shall be through windows, doors, louvers or other openings to the outdoors. The operating mechanism for such openings shall be provided with ready access so that the openings are readily controllable by the building occupants.

diagrams.title: Habitable Space: Light / Ventilation
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Per the Residential Code, Habitable Space is a space in a building for living, sleeping, eating or cooking. Bathrooms, toilet rooms, closets, halls, storage or utility spaces and similar areas are not considered habitable spaces.

Natural lighting and ventilation requirements are found in both the Residential and Building Codes. While both codes require 8% / 4% of the room area for light and ventilation, a difference exists regarding light and ventilation requirements from adjoining rooms (10% for Residential Code, vs. 8% for the Building Code.)

diagrams.title: Location of Vent Terminal (IPC)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Vent terminals should be kept a minimum distance away from openings or air intake openings to prevent sewer gases from entering the building. Verify with the local jurisdiction about the required extension of the vent terminal above the roof.

children.body: The openable area of the openings to the outdoors shall be not less than 4 percent of the floor area being ventilated.

Where rooms and spaces without openings to the outdoors are ventilated through an adjoining room, the opening to the adjoining room shall be unobstructed and shall have an area of not less than 8 percent of the floor area of the interior room or space, but not less than 25 square feet (2.3 m2). The openable area of the openings to the outdoors shall be based on the total floor area being ventilated.
Exception: Exterior openings required for ventilation shall be permitted to open into a sunroom with thermal isolation or a patio cover provided that the openable area between the sunroom addition or patio cover and the interior room shall have an area of not less than 8 percent of the floor area of the interior room or space, but not less than 20 square feet (1.86 m2). The openable area of the openings to the outdoors shall be based on the total floor area being ventilated.

diagrams.title: Habitable Space: Light / Ventilation
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Per the Residential Code, Habitable Space is a space in a building for living, sleeping, eating or cooking. Bathrooms, toilet rooms, closets, halls, storage or utility spaces and similar areas are not considered habitable spaces.

Natural lighting and ventilation requirements are found in both the Residential and Building Codes. While both codes require 8% / 4% of the room area for light and ventilation, a difference exists regarding light and ventilation requirements from adjoining rooms (10% for Residential Code, vs. 8% for the Building Code.)

children.body: Where openings below grade provide required natural ventilation, the outside horizontal clear space measured perpendicular to the opening shall be one and one-half times the depth of the opening. The depth of the opening shall be measured from the average adjoining ground level to the bottom of the opening.

diagrams.title: Natural Ventilation Openings Below Grade (IMC)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: In the Mechanical Code, natural ventilation for areas below grade does not have the advantage of breezes or the direct natural flow of air at the ground level. Therefore, a larger opening of the window well is required to provide the air needed. Where below grade windows are also used as emergency escape openings, window wells shall comply with the more restrictive of natural ventilation or minimum window well sizes for emergency escape windows.

children.body: Contaminant sources in naturally ventilated spaces shall be removed in accordance with the Florida Building Code, Mechanical and the Florida Fire Prevention Code.
Rooms containing bathtubs, showers, spas and similar bathing fixtures shall be mechanically ventilated in accordance with the Florida Building Code, Mechanical.
Where natural ventilation is to be provided by openings onto yards or courts, such yards or courts shall comply with Section 1206.

Ventilation and exhaust systems for occupancies and operations involving flammable or combustible hazards or other contaminant sources as covered in the Florida Building Code, Mechanical or the Florida Fire Prevention Code shall be provided as required by both codes.

Interior spaces intended for human occupancy shall be provided with active or passive space heating systems capable of maintaining an indoor temperature of not less than 68°F (20°C) at a point 3 feet (914 mm) above the floor on the design heating day.
Exceptions: Space heating systems are not required for:
  1. Interior spaces where the primary purpose of the space is not associated with human comfort.
  2. Group F, H, S or U occupancies.

diagrams.title: Heating Req:  Bldg. vs. Res. Code
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The definition for Habitable Spaces, says that toilet rooms are not included in the definition of habitable space. However, the 2012 Tennessee Property Maintenance Code, as an example, states that heating facilities are required in habitable rooms, bathrooms and toilet rooms. Care should be taken when excluding heating from rooms, including consideration of possible freezing of plumbing fixtures or possible future conversion to a habitable space. It appears possible to conform to the letter of the Residential Code while also not conforming to the Property Maintenance Code.

diagrams.title: Artificial Light
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Where natural lighting is not provided in spaces intended for human occupancy artificial lighting is required. The artificial light is required to achieve an average illumination level of 10 footcandles on an imaginary plane 30" above the entire floor of the space.

children.body: Every space intended for human occupancy shall be provided with natural light by means of exterior glazed openings in accordance with Section 1205.2 or shall be provided with artificial light in accordance with Section 1205.3. Exterior glazed openings shall open directly onto a public way or onto a yard or court in accordance with Section 1206.
The minimum net glazed area shall be not less than 8 percent of the floor area of the room served.

For the purpose of natural lighting, any room is permitted to be considered as a portion of an adjoining room where one-half of the area of the common wall is open and unobstructed and provides an opening of not less than one-tenth of the floor area of the interior room or 25 square feet (2.32 m2), whichever is greater.
Exception: Openings required for natural light shall be permitted to open into a sunroom with thermal isolation or a patio cover where the common wall provides a glazed area of not less than one-tenth of the floor area of the interior room or 20 square feet (1.86 m2), whichever is greater.

Exterior openings required by Section 1205.2 for natural light shall open directly onto a public way, yard or court, as set forth in Section 1206.
Exceptions:
  1. Required exterior openings are permitted to open into a roofed porch where the porch meets all of the following criteria:
    1. Abuts a public way, yard or court.
    2. Has a ceiling height of not less than 7 feet (2134 mm).
    3. Has a longer side at least 65 percent open and unobstructed.
  2. Skylights are not required to open directly onto a public way, yard or court.
Artificial light shall be provided that is adequate to provide an average illumination of 10 footcandles (107 lux) over the area of the room at a height of 30 inches (762 mm) above the floor level.

diagrams.title: Bathroom Light and Ventilation
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Natural light and ventilation is required in bathrooms and is typically provided by a operable window. Mechanical ventilation of bathrooms is required by the plumbing code by reference to the mechanical code (Table 403.3.2.3) and is typically provided by an exhaust fan. Providing natural light and ventilation may be omitted provided sufficient artificial light and mechanical ventilation, typically and exhaust fan, is provided. The level of artificial light required must provide an average of 10 fc at a plane 30" above the floor. The exhaust fan must be able to provide 50 cfm if intermittent (switched, humidistat, timer controlled) or 20 cfm if continuously operated. The duct from the exhaust fan must expel air directly to the exterior of the building, not attics or crawl or other spaces within the building envelope.

diagrams.title: Artificial Light
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Where natural lighting is not provided in spaces intended for human occupancy artificial lighting is required. The artificial light is required to achieve an average illumination level of 10 footcandles on an imaginary plane 30" above the entire floor of the space.

diagrams.title: Bathroom Light and Ventilation - Exception
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Natural light and ventilation is required in bathrooms and is typically provided by a operable window. Mechanical ventilation of bathrooms is required by the plumbing code by reference to the mechanical code (Table 403.3.2.3) and is typically provided by an exhaust fan. Providing natural light and ventilation may be omitted provided sufficient artificial light and mechanical ventilation, typically and exhaust fan, is provided. The level of artificial light required must provide an average of 10 fc at a plane 30" above the floor. The exhaust fan must be able to provide 50 cfm if intermittent (switched, humidistat, timer controlled) or 20 cfm if continuously operated. The duct from the exhaust fan must expel air directly to the exterior of the building, not attics or crawl or other spaces within the building envelope.

diagrams.title: Lighting Outlets - Guest Rooms / Suites
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The electrical code provides specific requirements, and exceptions, for guest rooms, which are generally Group R-1 occupancy, for transient individuals.

children.body: Stairways within dwelling units and exterior stairways serving a dwelling unit shall have an illumination level on tread runs of not less than 1 footcandle (11 lux). Stairways in other occupancies shall be governed by Chapter 10.

diagrams.title: Exterior Stair Illumination (RC)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Stairways require an illumination source to be used safely. Stairways to a basement would be those meeting the rise/run and other requirements of the stairway. Illumination would not be required at stairs covered by hinged bulkhead doors, where the height from the basement finished floor level to grade adjacent to the stairway is not more than 8 feet, per Section R311.7.10.2.

diagrams.title: Interior Stair Illumination (RC)
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
A foot-candle (fc) is a unit of illuminance, representing the amount of light that falls onto a surface. It is defined as one lumen per square foot. To visualize what one foot-candle of illuminance looks like, consider the following description:

Imagine a single candle lit in a completely dark room. If you were to measure the light falling on a one-square-foot surface situated one foot away from the candle (in direct line with the flame and without any obstructions), that would be approximately equivalent to one foot-candle of illuminance.

In practical terms, this is a rather low level of light, akin to the soft, dim light you might experience in a room illuminated only by candlelight. It's more than enough to make out shapes and some details, but it's much dimmer than the lighting levels we're used to in well-lit indoor spaces. To put it into perspective, a typical home living room in the evening with artificial light might range from 10 to 50 foot-candles, whereas an office lighting is typically brighter, often around 30 to 50 foot-candles.

children.body: The control for activation of the required stairway lighting shall be in accordance with NFPA 70.
The means of egress shall be illuminated in accordance with Section 1008.1.

diagrams.title: Occupant Loads: Outdoor Areas
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Section 1004.7 is to ensure that Outdoor Areas have adequate means for emergency evacuation. It gives the building official the authority to determine the occupant load for outdoor areas. It establishes that the Means of Egress for Outdoor Areas be established per the requirements of Chapter 10 of the building code, the same requirements as any other room or space. It provides exceptions for outdoor areas used exclusively for servicing the building and outdoor areas serving R-3 buildings and R-2 dwelling units.

diagrams.title: Yards for Light and Ventilation
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Section 1205 is to ensure that yards required to provide rooms with light and air are of adequate size. The code defines the minimum required yard width. 3' minimum is required for lightwells 2 stories or less in height. For lightwells from 3 to 14 stories the required width (W) needs to be increased by 1' for each story greater than 2 (W = 3' + (H-2)'. The required yard width for Lightwells over 14 stories tall are to be calculated as though the lightwell is 14 stories tall (W = 3'+(14-2)' = 15').

children.body: This section shall apply to yards and courts adjacent to exterior openings that provide natural light or ventilation. Such yards and courts shall be on the same lot as the building.

Yards shall be not less than 3 feet (914 mm) in width for buildings two stories or less above grade plane. For buildings more than two stories above grade plane, the minimum width of the yard shall be increased at the rate of 1 foot (305 mm) for each additional story. For buildings exceeding 14 stories above grade plane, the required width of the yard shall be computed on the basis of 14 stories above grade plane.

diagrams.title: Yards for Light and Ventilation
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Section 1205 is to ensure that yards required to provide rooms with light and air are of adequate size. The code defines the minimum required yard width. 3' minimum is required for lightwells 2 stories or less in height. For lightwells from 3 to 14 stories the required width (W) needs to be increased by 1' for each story greater than 2 (W = 3' + (H-2)'. The required yard width for Lightwells over 14 stories tall are to be calculated as though the lightwell is 14 stories tall (W = 3'+(14-2)' = 15').

children.body: Courts shall be not less than 3 feet (914 mm) in width. Courts having windows opening on opposite sides shall be not less than 6 feet (1829 mm) in width. Courts shall be not less than 10 feet (3048 mm) in length unless bounded on one end by a public way or yard. For buildings more than two stories above grade plane, the court shall be increased 1 foot (305 mm) in width and 2 feet (610 mm) in length for each additional story. For buildings exceeding 14 stories above grade plane, the required dimensions shall be computed on the basis of 14 stories above grade plane.
Access shall be provided to the bottom of courts for cleaning purposes.

Courts more than two stories in height shall be provided with a horizontal air intake at the bottom not less than 10 square feet (0.93 m2) in area and leading to the exterior of the building unless abutting a yard or public way.
The bottom of every court shall be properly graded and drained to a public sewer or other approved disposal system complying with the Florida Building Code, Plumbing.

diagrams.title: Noise Control (Hospitals)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: To ensure that patients' healing is not disturbed by excessive noise, the hospital guideline has noise criteria that applies to patient areas. To protect the patients from being disturbed by impact noises recreation, exercise, equipment and similar spaces that generate impact noises are not allowed to be directly over patient bed areas, deliver or operating suites unless special noise reduction provisions are provided. To ensure that patient areas are sufficiently quiet the FGI provides minimum STC (sound transmission class) criteria in table 1.2-6 for patient area ceilings, floors and walls.

children.body: This section shall apply to common interior walls, partitions and floor/ceiling assemblies between adjacent dwelling units and sleeping units or between dwelling units and sleeping units and adjacent public areas such as halls, corridors, stairways or service areas.

Walls, partitions and floor/ceiling assemblies separating dwelling units and sleeping units from each other or from public or service areas shall have a sound transmission class of not less than 50 where tested in accordance with ASTM E90, or have a Normalized Noise Isolation Class (NNIC) rating of not less than 45 if field tested in accordance with ASTM E336 for airborne noise. Alternatively, the sound transmission class of walls, partitions and floor/ceiling assemblies shall be established by engineering analysis based on a comparison of walls, partitions and floor/ceiling assemblies having sound transmission class ratings as determined by the test procedures set forth in ASTM E90. Penetrations or openings in construction assemblies for piping; electrical devices; recessed cabinets; bathtubs; soffits; or heating, ventilating or exhaust ducts shall be sealed, lined, insulated or otherwise treated to maintain the required ratings. This requirement shall not apply to entrance doors; however, such doors shall be tight fitting to the frame and sill.

diagrams.title: Airborne Sound Transmission (2021)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Sound travels either through air as a medium or through vibrations due to impacts or vibrations of an assembly due to the sound waves themselves. In order to reduce the airborne transmission of sound through an assembly, locations through which air can pass need to be appropriately constructed in a way to reduce the passage of air. Those parts of the assembly used to reduce sound transmission must also comply with the provisions of Section 720 when also a part of fire-resistive construction.

diagrams.title: NICU Sound Ratings
diagrams.descriptionHtml: In order to ensure that neonatal intensive care unit's (NICU) environments are sufficiently quiet for the new born patients, the code calls for minimum sound transmissions coefficients (STC) for the various walls, floors and ceilings that separate NICU's from other functions within the hospital. The required STC separation rating is called out in table A2.2-a, varies from 40 to 65 and is dependent on the adjacent spaces use/function.

diagrams.title: Two-Family Dwelling Separation
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Dwelling Unit: A single unit providing complete independent living facilities for one or more persons, including permanent provisions for living, sleeping, eating, cooking and sanitation.

Draft Stop: A material, device or construction installed to restrict the movement of air within open spaces of concealed areas of building components such as crawl spaces, floor-ceiling assemblies, roof-ceiling assemblies and attics.

Two dwelling units can be structures known as "duplexes" or ADU's (Accessory Dwelling Units in some jurisdictions. When altering an existing residence to create a second unit, attention should be paid to the continuity of the dwelling separation between the existing dwelling and the new dwelling. This could require unexpected work to be required in the crawlspace (if present) or in the attic.

In certain jurisdictions, two family dwellings may be governed by either the Building Code or Residential Code (but provisions may not be mixed). In the Building Code, similar wall and floor separations are known as Fire Partitions (Section 708) and Horizontal Assemblies (Section 711). See also Section 420 for additional building code requirements.

children.body: The sound transmission class of concrete masonry and clay masonry assemblies shall be calculated in accordance with TMS 0302 or determined through testing in accordance with ASTM E90.

Floor/ceiling assemblies between dwelling units and sleeping units or between a dwelling unit or sleeping unit and a public or service area within the structure shall have an impact insulation class rating of not less than 50 where tested in accordance with ASTM E492, or have an Apparent Impact Insulation Class (AIIC) of not less than 45 if field tested in accordance with ASTM E1007. Alternatively, the impact insulation class of floor/ceiling assemblies shall be established by engineering analysis based on a comparison of floor/ceiling assemblies having impact insulation class ratings as determined by the test procedures set forth in ASTM E492.

diagrams.title: Structure-Borne Sound
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Structure borne sound is sound transferred through the assembly by the impact or vibration of the actual phyisical materials. Some methods to reduce this sound transmission includes sound reducing mats between the flooring and the substrate on top of the floor. Also, the use of resilient light gauge metal channels on the bottom of joists can also help reduce transmission of structure borne sound.

children.body: Habitable spaces, other than a kitchen, shall be not less than 7 feet (2134 mm) in any plan dimension. Kitchens shall have a clear passageway of not less than 3 feet (914 mm) between counter fronts and appliances or counter fronts and walls.

diagrams.title: Habitable Space: Light / Ventilation
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Per the Residential Code, Habitable Space is a space in a building for living, sleeping, eating or cooking. Bathrooms, toilet rooms, closets, halls, storage or utility spaces and similar areas are not considered habitable spaces.

Natural lighting and ventilation requirements are found in both the Residential and Building Codes. While both codes require 8% / 4% of the room area for light and ventilation, a difference exists regarding light and ventilation requirements from adjoining rooms (10% for Residential Code, vs. 8% for the Building Code.)

diagrams.title: Efficiency Dwelling Units: 2021
diagrams.descriptionHtml: An efficiency dwelling unit provides for a minimal amount of living space where all living functions except the bathroom and one closet are within the same space.

diagrams.title: Pass-Through Kitchens: Countertop Clearances
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Per the FHA Design Manual: "The Guidelines require a clearance of at least 40 inches between all opposing base cabinets, countertops, appliances, and walls. The 40-inch clearance is measured from any countertop or the face of any appliance (excluding handles and controls) that projects into the kitchen to the opposing cabinet, countertop, appliance, or wall. Refrigerators vary greatly in depth and may extend up to eight inches beyond cabinet faces. Standard free-standing and drop-in ranges may project up to three inches. Appliance depths (excluding door handles) must be included when calculating the 40-inch clearances."

State and local codes and regulations should be consulted. In addition, if a project scoping falls under the scoping of both the FHA and ADA Standards, the most restrictive of both sets of regulations apply, per DOJ / HUD Joint statement and the Advisory 224.1, in addition to state and local regulations.

children.body:
Occupiable spaces, habitable spaces and corridors shall have a ceiling height of not less than 7 feet 6 inches (2286 mm) above the finished floor. Bathrooms, toilet rooms, kitchens, storage rooms and laundry rooms shall have a ceiling height of not less than 7 feet (2134 mm) above the finished floor.
Exceptions:
  1. In one- and two-family dwellings, beams or girders spaced not less than 4 feet (1219 mm) on center shall be permitted to project not more than 6 inches (152 mm) below the required ceiling height.
  2. If any room in a building has a sloped ceiling, the prescribed ceiling height for the room is required in one-half the area thereof. Any portion of the room measuring less than 5 feet (1524 mm) from the finished floor to the ceiling shall not be included in any computation of the minimum area thereof.
  3. The height of mezzanines and spaces below mezzanines shall be in accordance with Section 505.1.
  4. Corridors contained within a dwelling unit or sleeping unit in a Group R occupancy shall have a ceiling height of not less than 7 feet (2134 mm) above the finished floor.

diagrams.title: Electrical Panel - Work Space Height
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Electrical panels shall be provided with a clear work space of 36" by 30" minimum from the floor up to a height of 6'-6". However, In existing dwelling units where the electrical service panel is less than 200 amperes, the height of the working space is allowed to be less than 6'-6".

diagrams.title: Min. Means of Egress Ceiling Heights
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Provisions for minimum ceiling heights include the minimum allowed heights to ceilings, protrusions, headers and other structural elements and mechanical or plumbing systems including fire sprinklers. The provisions provide allowances in dwelling units for the provision of space for ventilation in corridors (by use of a reduced ceiling height) or the condition where a room walls include the sloping roof, which reduces the ceiling height in a portion of the room. There are exceptions in the existing building code where pre-existing non-conforming ceiling heights may be allowed to remain.

diagrams.title: Res. Fixture Clearances (IPC vs. UPC)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Fixture clearances shown apply to non-accessible / ADA conditions. Verify with multifamily housing or accessible fixture clearance requirements when fixtures are required to be accessible.

children.body: Any room with a furred ceiling shall be required to have the minimum ceiling height in two-thirds of the area thereof, but in no case shall the height of the furred ceiling be less than 7 feet (2134 mm).

Every dwelling unit shall have no fewer than one room that shall have not less than 120 square feet (11.2 m2) of net floor area. Other habitable rooms shall have a net floor area of not less than 70 square feet (6.5 m2).
Exception: Kitchens are not required to be of a minimum floor area.

diagrams.title: Habitable Space: Light / Ventilation
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Per the Residential Code, Habitable Space is a space in a building for living, sleeping, eating or cooking. Bathrooms, toilet rooms, closets, halls, storage or utility spaces and similar areas are not considered habitable spaces.

Natural lighting and ventilation requirements are found in both the Residential and Building Codes. While both codes require 8% / 4% of the room area for light and ventilation, a difference exists regarding light and ventilation requirements from adjoining rooms (10% for Residential Code, vs. 8% for the Building Code.)

children.body:
Efficiency dwelling units shall conform to the requirements of the code except as modified herein:
  1. The unit shall have a living room of not less than 190 square feet (17.7 m2) of floor area.
  2. The unit shall be provided with a separate closet.
  3. The unit shall be provided with a kitchen sink, cooking appliance and refrigeration facilities, each having a clear working space of not less than 30 inches (762 mm) in front. Light and ventilation conforming to this code shall be provided.
  4. The unit shall be provided with a separate bathroom containing a water closet, lavatory and bathtub or shower.

diagrams.title: Efficiency Dwelling Units: 2021
diagrams.descriptionHtml: An efficiency dwelling unit provides for a minimal amount of living space where all living functions except the bathroom and one closet are within the same space.

diagrams.title: Electrical Equipment with Limited Access
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Section 110.26 of the electrical code is to ensure that electrical equipment installed in locations with limited access may be safely serviced. The section only applies to equipment of 1000 volts or less to ground that require adjustment, or maintenance while energized. The section establishes the minimum opening size required to access the equipment service workspace and the required size of the workspace. Where Equipment workspace access is through a lay in ceiling the opening may not be smaller than 22 inches by 22 inches. Where equipment workspace access is through a floor the opening may not be smaller than 22 inches by 30 inches. Note that the 22x22 is for a lay in ceiling, and not an attic space. Building codes require a 22x30 opening, similar to "crawl space" as discussed in the electrical code.

The minimum size of the workspace width is the greater of 30 inches or the width of the equipment. The minimum depth or space in front of the equipment is established in Table 110.26(A)(1). The minimum height of the workspace in front of the equipment is the height required to install the equipment from within the limited space. Any access panels that are part of the equipment enclosure are required to be able to be opened at least 90 degrees into the work area. Access openings and ceiling structural members may overlap the required workspace area.

children.body: Crawl spaces shall be provided with not fewer than one access opening that shall be not less than 18 inches by 24 inches (457 mm by 610 mm).

An opening not less than 20 inches by 30 inches (559 mm by 762 mm) shall be provided to any attic area having a clear height of over 30 inches (762 mm). Clear headroom of not less than 30 inches (762 mm) shall be provided in the attic space at or above the access opening.

diagrams.title: Attic Access
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Attic access to areas of sufficient height or area are required to provide access for service of mechanical equipment, insulation or other uses of the attic. Attic access can be provided within the unit. Attic access would need to be provided on each side of a draft stop or wall extension provided due to a two-family dwelling condition. The Building Code and Residential Codes (2018) have two different requirements that dictate whether attic access is required, and two different measurements for the opening size.

children.body: Access to mechanical appliances installed in under-floor areas, in attic spaces and on roofs or elevated structures shall be in accordance with the Florida Building Code, Mechanical.

diagrams.title: Water Heater, Appliances: Attics
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The requirements for installation of water heaters is based on NFPA 54. Other requirements apply related to plumbing, electrical and structural considerations for installation of water heaters and other equipment in attics and crawlspaces.

diagrams.title: Access to Under-floor appliances
diagrams.descriptionHtml: When an appliance is installed in and under floor space it must be serviceable and removable with out having to modify the underfloor space. A level service area is required on the front/service side of the appliance that is 30" wide x 30" deep x 30" tall. The appliance must be within 20' of an access opening that is large enough to remove the appliance or at least 22" wide by 30" tall, whichever is larger. A 22' wide by 30" tall passageway is required from the access opening to the appliance. The code allows for an unlimited distance from the opening to the appliance if the passageway and access 6' tall, 22" wide and unobstructed. A passageway is not required where the access opening provide direct access to the required service area and the appliance can be serviced and removed through the access opening.

diagrams.title: Building Subdrains to Sumps
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Building Subdrain: That portion of a drainage system that does not drain by gravity into the building sewer. Building drainage that can't be naturally discharged to the sewer due to a lack of gravity flow has to be discharged into a suitably covered and vented sump. From this point, the accumulated liquid has to be automatically lifted and conveyed into the building's gravity drainage system or removed through other approved means. This might occur in a building with basement levels where the plumbing fixtures are installed below the level of the building sewer and public sewer or in areas of the building that are lower than the main drainage system, such as a sunken bathtub or a bathroom installed in a basement, making gravity drainage impossible.

Of note, the electrical code does not require a single receptacle supplying a permanently installed sump pump to have ground-fault circuit-interrupter (GFCI) protection if permanently wired in the 2020 code version. Older electrical codes don't require GFCI if the pump is permanently installed, but makes no mention of requiring permanent wiring. Verify the applicable year for your jurisdiction to ensure code compliant electrical installation of sump pumps.

diagrams.title: Efficiency Dwelling Units: 2021
diagrams.descriptionHtml: An efficiency dwelling unit provides for a minimal amount of living space where all living functions except the bathroom and one closet are within the same space.

diagrams.title: Toilet Paper Dispensers: Recessed (ADA)
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
The toilet paper dispenser needs to meet a number of clearances that provide for forward reach availability for someone using the toilet, as well as vertical reach. The distances should be measured to the location where the operation occurs, i.e. where the toilet paper comes out of the dispensing device. Clearance to provide for usability of the grab bars also need to be provided. Check also with state or local accessibility requirements for more restrictive scoping, clearance or installation requirements.

ADA Advisory: Section 604.7 Dispensers. If toilet paper dispensers are installed above the side wall grab bar, the outlet of the toilet paper dispenser must be 48 inches maximum above the finish floor and the top of the gripping surface of the grab bar must be 33 inches minimum and 36 inches maximum above the finish floor.

Verify additional requirements of A117.1 (where adopted) or local requirements.

diagrams.title: Toilet Paper Dispenser: Non-Recessed (ADA)
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
The toilet paper dispenser needs to meet a number of clearances that provide for forward reach availability for someone using the toilet, as well as vertical reach. The distances should be measured to the location where the operation occurs, i.e. where the toilet paper comes out of the dispensing device. Clearance to provide for usability of the grab bars also need to be provided. Check also with state or local accessibility requirements for more restrictive scoping, clearance or installation requirements.

ADA Advisory: Section 604.7 Dispensers. If toilet paper dispensers are installed above the side wall grab bar, the outlet of the toilet paper dispenser must be 48 inches maximum above the finish floor and the top of the gripping surface of the grab bar must be 33 inches minimum and 36 inches maximum above the finish floor.

Verify additional requirements of A117.1 (where adopted) or local requirements.

diagrams.title: Shower Controls (without seat) and Thresholds
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
In a standard roll-in compartment without a seat, the controls, faucet, and shower spray unit can be located on any of the three walls. They must be located above grab bars and within accessible reach range. Shower controls and fittings must be at least 11/2" above the grab bar so that they do not impede the bar's gripping surface. Enclosures cannot obstruct controls, faucets, shower spray units or transfer to seats.

Thresholds at roll-in showers must comply with specifications for changes in level to allow access to wheeled mobility aids. While a threshold height up to 1/2" (if properly beveled) is permitted, trench drains and other designs that allow a flush transition to the shower floor will provide easier access. Shower floors can slope to drains (a 1:48 maximum slope will help control water without impacting accessibility). Where floor drains are provided in bathing rooms, it is important that the slope of the floor not exceed the 1:48 minimum cross slope.
Source: access-board.gov

Note that A117.1, California Building Code and Minnesota Accessibility Code does not have provisions for a compartment without a seat, like is shown in the ADA Standards. Showers without seats assumes the user will have a special separate seating or wheelchair device for bathing. It is not likely a user will shower in the wheelchair used for daily use.

diagrams.title: Doors: Patient Bathing / Toilet Facilities (Hospitals)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: In the Hospital Guidelines, because patient bathroom doors need to enable rescue access without hitting the occupant when opening the door, configurations allowed are as follows: a single out swinging door, two separate doors, a door with emergency rescue hardware, or a non-pocket sliding door. Visual privacy to toilet and bathing rooms that open to public areas or corridors also needs to be provided.

diagrams.title: Walls and Partitions in Bathrooms and Toilet Rooms
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Walls within 2' of toilets, urinals and lavatories are required to be finished in a smooth, hard, nonabsorbent surface to 48" minimum above the finished flooring. Shower enclosure walls and walls above tubs with a shower head are required to have a smooth nonabsorbent finish to a height not less than 72" above the drain inlet.

diagrams.title: Luminaires in Bathtub and Shower Areas
Receptacles at Bathtub and Shower Spaces
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Electrical fixtures and outlets are not allowed within the shower or tub enclosure and the volume in the bathroom within 3' of the enclosure from the floor to 8' above the shower curb or top of the tub. The code provides exceptions for hydromassage bathtub power and weight supporting light fixture outlets for listed light fixtures. Where there is no space less than 3' from the enclosure for the required lavatory outlet or to power an electronic toilet the code provides an exception to that allows the outlets to be placed within the 3' of the enclosure.

diagrams.title: Registers, Grilles and Diffusers - Prohibited Locations
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Duct systems are required to provide volume dampers for balancing of the system. The volume dampers are required at each branch duct or at each register, grill or diffuser. All volume dampers required to balance the system must be able to be accessed. In toilet and bathing rooms, registers, grilles and diffusers are not allowed in the floors, the flooring base, or on walls within both 48" of the floor and 24" of a fixture. Floor registers need to be able to resist a 200 lb force applied to a 2" diameter disk applied at the registers weakest location.

diagrams.title: Bathtubs and Showers: Surfaces and Joints
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Shower enclosure wall surfaces are required to be both smooth and nonabsorbent. The smooth nonabsorbent wall surfaces must extend to a height that is 72" minimum above the shower drain inlet. Where a shower head is installed above a bathtub the walls surfaces enclosing the tub need to meet the same requirements as a shower enclosure wall. Where a built-in tub is provided with a shower, the joint where the tub meets an adjacent enclosing wall is required to be waterproof.

children.body: The number and type of plumbing fixtures provided in any occupancy shall comply with Chapter 29.

diagrams.title: Plumbing Fixture Count: Retail
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The calculation shown is based on Section 2902 of the building code using the occupant load factors of Section 1004, assuming half of the occupants are male and half are female. Other states and local jurisdictions may allow other methods which may provide a reduced occupant load, such as certain uses in California such as public schools or state owned buildings (See CPC 422.1, Table 4-1 for example). In addition, other plumbing codes may supersede Chapter 29 and/or have different plumbing fixture ratios than those shown here.

children.body: Walls, floors and partitions in toilet and bathrooms shall comply with Sections 1210.2.1 through 1210.2.4.

diagrams.title: Urinals and Partitions
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Urinals are required to have privacy partitions in accordance with building code 1209.3.2. When such partitions are provided, the clearance between them shall comply with ADA Standards 605. When the space that a wheelchair uses exceeds 24", the area is treated like a deep alcove to be able to give the user room to maneuver backward to get out of the space. See building and plumbing codes for the required numbers of fixtures, and ADA Standards 213.3.3 for the number of urinals required to be accessible. Check also with state or local accessibility requirements for more restrictive scoping, clearance or installation requirements.

diagrams.title: Registers, Grilles and Diffusers - Prohibited Locations
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Duct systems are required to provide volume dampers for balancing of the system. The volume dampers are required at each branch duct or at each register, grill or diffuser. All volume dampers required to balance the system must be able to be accessed. In toilet and bathing rooms, registers, grilles and diffusers are not allowed in the floors, the flooring base, or on walls within both 48" of the floor and 24" of a fixture. Floor registers need to be able to resist a 200 lb force applied to a 2" diameter disk applied at the registers weakest location.

children.body: In other than dwelling units, toilet, bathing and shower room floor finish materials shall have a smooth, hard, nonabsorbent surface. The intersections of such floors with walls shall have a smooth, hard, nonabsorbent vertical base that extends upward onto the walls not less than 4 inches (102 mm).

diagrams.title: Bathroom Wall Bases
diagrams.descriptionHtml: A wall base is commonly used in installation of hard surface flooring to cover an expansion gap, cuts when installation of tile or stone has occurred, or in hospitality or commercial settings to provide a sanitary and cleanable edge treatment to prevent damage to the wall.

children.body:
Walls and partitions within 2 feet (610 mm) of service sinks, urinals and water closets shall have a smooth, hard, nonabsorbent surface, to a height of not less than 4 feet (1219 mm) above the floor, and except for structural elements, the materials used in such walls shall be of a type that is not adversely affected by moisture.
Exception: This section does not apply to the following buildings and spaces:
  1. Dwelling units and sleeping units.
  2. Toilet rooms that are not accessible to the public and that have not more than one water closet.
Accessories such as grab bars, towel bars, paper dispensers and soap dishes, provided on or within walls, shall be installed and sealed to protect structural elements from moisture.

diagrams.title: Urinals and Partitions
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Urinals are required to have privacy partitions in accordance with building code 1209.3.2. When such partitions are provided, the clearance between them shall comply with ADA Standards 605. When the space that a wheelchair uses exceeds 24", the area is treated like a deep alcove to be able to give the user room to maneuver backward to get out of the space. See building and plumbing codes for the required numbers of fixtures, and ADA Standards 213.3.3 for the number of urinals required to be accessible. Check also with state or local accessibility requirements for more restrictive scoping, clearance or installation requirements.

diagrams.title: Walls and Partitions in Bathrooms and Toilet Rooms
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Walls within 2' of toilets, urinals and lavatories are required to be finished in a smooth, hard, nonabsorbent surface to 48" minimum above the finished flooring. Shower enclosure walls and walls above tubs with a shower head are required to have a smooth nonabsorbent finish to a height not less than 72" above the drain inlet.

children.body: Shower compartments and walls above bathtubs with installed shower heads shall be finished with a smooth, nonabsorbent surface to a height not less than 72 inches (1829 mm) above the drain inlet.

diagrams.title: Bathtubs and Showers: Surfaces and Joints
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Shower enclosure wall surfaces are required to be both smooth and nonabsorbent. The smooth nonabsorbent wall surfaces must extend to a height that is 72" minimum above the shower drain inlet. Where a shower head is installed above a bathtub the walls surfaces enclosing the tub need to meet the same requirements as a shower enclosure wall. Where a built-in tub is provided with a shower, the joint where the tub meets an adjacent enclosing wall is required to be waterproof.

children.body: Built-in tubs with showers shall have waterproof joints between the tub and adjacent wall.

diagrams.title: Bathtubs and Showers: Surfaces and Joints
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Shower enclosure wall surfaces are required to be both smooth and nonabsorbent. The smooth nonabsorbent wall surfaces must extend to a height that is 72" minimum above the shower drain inlet. Where a shower head is installed above a bathtub the walls surfaces enclosing the tub need to meet the same requirements as a shower enclosure wall. Where a built-in tub is provided with a shower, the joint where the tub meets an adjacent enclosing wall is required to be waterproof.

children.body:
Public restrooms shall be visually screened from outside entry or exit doorways to ensure user privacy within the restroom. This provision shall also apply where mirrors would compromise personal privacy. Privacy at water closets and urinals shall be provided in accordance with Sections 1210.3.1 and 1210.3.2.
Exception: Visual screening shall not be required for single-occupant toilet rooms with a lockable door.

Each water closet utilized by the public or employees shall occupy a separate compartment with walls or partitions and a door enclosing the fixtures to ensure privacy.
Exceptions:
  1. Water closet compartments shall not be required in a single-occupant toilet room with a lockable door.
  2. Toilet rooms located in child day care facilities and containing two or more water closets shall be permitted to have one water closet without an enclosing compartment.
  3. This provision is not applicable to toilet areas located within Group I-3 occupancy housing areas.

Each urinal utilized by the public or employees shall occupy a separate area with walls or partitions to provide privacy. The walls or partitions shall begin at a height not more than 12 inches (305 mm) from and extend not less than 60 inches (1524 mm) above the finished floor surface. The walls or partitions shall extend from the wall surface at each side of the urinal not less than 18 inches (457 mm) or to a point not less than 6 inches (152 mm) beyond the outermost front lip of the urinal measured from the finished backwall surface, whichever is greater.
Exceptions:
  1. Urinal partitions shall not be required in a single-occupant or family or assisted-use toilet room with a lockable door.
  2. Toilet rooms located in child day care facilities and containing two or more urinals shall be permitted to have one urinal without partitions.

diagrams.title: Urinals and Partitions
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Urinals are required to have privacy partitions in accordance with building code 1209.3.2. When such partitions are provided, the clearance between them shall comply with ADA Standards 605. When the space that a wheelchair uses exceeds 24", the area is treated like a deep alcove to be able to give the user room to maneuver backward to get out of the space. See building and plumbing codes for the required numbers of fixtures, and ADA Standards 213.3.3 for the number of urinals required to be accessible. Check also with state or local accessibility requirements for more restrictive scoping, clearance or installation requirements.

children.body: Enhanced classroom acoustics, where required in this section, shall comply with Section 808 of ICC A117.1.
In Group E occupancies, enhanced classroom acoustics shall be provided in all classrooms with a volume of 20,000 cubic feet (566 m3) or less.
